questions.text: Oral abortifacient is contraindicated in all the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oral abortifacients are medications that induce abortion or miscarriage.
  • Mifepristone in combination with Misoprostol is 95 per cent successful in terminating pregnancies of upto 9 week's duration with minimum complications.
  • The commonly used regimen is Mifepristone 200 mg orally on day 1, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally either immediately or within 6-8 hours. The other regimen is a dose of mifepristone 600 mg on day one, followed by 400 mcg orally of misoprostol on day three.
  • Commercially it comes as MTP kit having combipack tablets of mifepristone 200 mg one tablet and misoprostol 200 mcg 4 tablets (800 mcg).
  • The patient should return for a follow-up visit approximately 14 days after the administration of mifepristone to confirm by clinical examination or ultrasonographic scan that a complete termination of pregnancy has occurred.
  • Surgical termination is recommended to manage medical abortion treatment failures.

Contraindications:

  1. History of allergy to mifepristone, misoprostol, or other prostaglandins
  2. Confirmed or suspected ectopic pregnancy or undiagnosed adnexal mass
  3. IUD in place (Option A ruled out)
  4. Chronic Adrenal failure (Option B ruled out)
  5. Haemorrhagic disorder / Concurrent anticoagulant therapy
  6. Inherited porphyria (Option D ruled out)
  7. If a patient does not have adequate access to medical facilities equipped to provide emergency treatment of incomplete abortion and blood transfusion.

questions.text: World health day is celebrated on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • World Health Day is celebrated annually on April 7th.
  • It is a global health awareness day observed under the sponsorship of the World Health Organization (WHO).
  • The day marks the anniversary of the founding of WHO in 1948.
  • Each year, World Health Day focuses on a specific health theme or issue of global concern, aiming to raise awareness, mobilize support, and advocate for action to address pressing health challenges around the world.

Incorrect options:

June 5th (Option A): June 5th is observed as World Environment Day, focusing on environmental issues and sustainability. It is organized by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) to raise awareness and encourage action to protect the environment.

March 24th (Option B): March 24th is observed as World Tuberculosis Day, dedicated to raising awareness about the global epidemic of tuberculosis (TB) and efforts to eliminate the disease.

April 2nd (Option C): April 2nd is observed as World Autism Awareness Day, designated by the United Nations to raise awareness about autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and promote inclusion and understanding of individuals with autism.

Reference: World Health Day (who.int)

questions.text: Which of the following is the universal health insurance program in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ayushman Bharat, also known as the Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), is the universal health insurance program in India.
  • It was launched by the Government of India in September 2018 with the aim of providing financial protection to over 500 million vulnerable and economically disadvantaged people against catastrophic healthcare expenditures.
  • Ayushman Bharat is considered the world's largest government-funded healthcare program.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

RSBY (Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana) (Option A): While RSBY was a health insurance scheme launched in India in 2008, it primarily targeted below-poverty-line families and certain categories of unorganized workers. It aimed to provide them with cashless health insurance coverage for hospitalization expenses up to a certain limit. However, Ayushman Bharat (PM-JAY) has replaced RSBY and expanded the scope to cover a much larger population, making it the more relevant option for a universal health insurance program in India.

Atal Bimit Vyakti Kalyan Yojna (Option B): This is a social security scheme launched by the Employees' State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) in India. It provides relief to insured persons who become unemployed due to various contingencies such as closure of factory, retrenchment, or permanent invalidity.

Central Government Health Scheme (CGHS) (Option D):

  • This scheme was started in the year 1954 and provides comprehensive health care facilities for central government officials and pensioners residing in cities.
  • Operations of this scheme take place in cities such as Kolkata, Mumbai, Lucknow, Delhi, Nagpur, and Pune.
  • The scheme aims to make healthcare accessible and affordable for its beneficiaries by offering subsidized rates and cashless treatment options in empanelled hospitals

questions.text: Folic acid dosage for a woman with h/o first child born with some neural tube defect:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Folic acid supplementation is recommended for women who have had a previous child born with a Neural tube defect (NTD) to reduce the risk of recurrence in subsequent pregnancies.
  • Neural tube defects are birth defects of the brain, spine, or spinal cord, such as spina bifida or anencephaly, which can occur during early fetal development.
  • The standard dosage of folic acid for women with a history of a previous child born with an NTD is 4mg per day.
  • This higher dosage is recommended because these women are at a higher risk of having another child with an NTD, and higher doses of folic acid have been shown to reduce this risk more effectively.

Reference: Folic Acid Recommendations | CDC

questions.text: What is the schedule of Vitamin A for a child weighing < 8 kg showing signs of vitamin A deficiency ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a standard dosage of 1,00,000 IU of vitamin A for children weighing less than 8 kg, or if less than 1 year of age.

Vitamin A supplementation is crucial for children to prevent vitamin A deficiency, which can lead to serious health complications, including Vision problems and Impaired immune function.

questions.text: A child with fever, swelling in neck and testis is presenting to you. Parents giving h/o of 2 more children having similar symptoms in the village. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Given the presentation of fever, swelling in the neck (parotitis), and swelling in the testis, the most likely diagnosis is mumps. Additionally, the history of two other children in the village having similar symptoms further supports the likelihood of mumps as the diagnosis, as it suggests a community outbreak.

Mumps is a viral infection caused by the mumps virus, characterized by fever and swelling of the salivary glands, particularly the parotid glands located in the neck. In addition to parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands), mumps can also cause swelling of the testicles (orchitis) in males, which is known as mumps orchitis.

Incorrect options:

Measles (Option A): Measles is a viral infection caused by the measles virus. It typically presents with fever, cough, runny nose, and a characteristic rash. While fever may be present in both measles and mumps, the absence of characteristic symptoms such as cough and rash, along with the presence of swelling in the neck and testis, makes measles less likely as the diagnosis.

Rubella (Option C): Rubella, also known as German measles, is a viral infection caused by the rubella virus. It typically presents with a mild rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. While fever and swollen lymph nodes may be present in both rubella and mumps, the absence of a characteristic rash and the presence of swelling in the testis make rubella less likely as the diagnosis.

Diphtheria (Option D): Diphtheria is a bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It typically presents with a sore throat, fever, and a characteristic grayish membrane covering the throat and tonsils. Swelling in the neck may occur due to enlarged lymph nodes, but swelling in the testis is not a typical symptom of diphtheria. Additionally, the history of similar symptoms in other children in the village is not consistent with a diagnosis of diphtheria.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with multiple painless, beefy-red, granulomatous ulcers in the inguinal region that bleed easily on contact. The patient reports a recent sexual encounter during travel to a tropical region He is diagnosed as having Donovanosis. Which of these is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Donovanosis, also known as Granuloma inguinale, is a Chronic bacterial infection that primarily affects the skin and mucous membranes of the genital area.
  • It is caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Transmission: Through sexual contact
  • Symptoms: The infection often presents as painless, slowly progressive, ulcerative lesions on the genitals or perineum. These lesions can be highly vascular and bleed easily.

Incorrect options:

T. pallidum (Treponema pallidum) (option A): Treponema pallidum is the causative organism of syphilis, not donovanosis. Syphilis presents with distinct clinical manifestations, such as painless ulcers (chancres), rashes, and systemic symptoms. It is not associated with the characteristic lesions seen in donovanosis.

Chlamydia trachomatis (option B): Chlamydia trachomatis is a common sexually transmitted bacterium that can cause various infections, including chlamydia. However, it is not the causative organism of donovanosis. Chlamydia infections typically present with symptoms such as urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), rather than the characteristic lesions of donovanosis.

Herpes simplex (Option C): Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is responsible for genital herpes, a viral infection characterized by painful genital ulcers. While genital herpes can cause genital lesions similar in appearance to those of donovanosis, the causative organism of donovanosis is Klebsiella granulomatis, not herpes simplex virus.

questions.text: For a case presenting with Trachoma in a PHC OPD, SAFE strategy was applied. Which one of the following is not a component of SAFE strategy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The SAFE strategy is a comprehensive approach recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the control and elimination of trachoma, a neglected tropical disease caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.

The components of the SAFE strategy are as follows:

  1. Surgery for trichiasis: Trachomatous trichiasis (TT) is the advanced stage of trachoma where the eyelashes turn inward and rub against the cornea, causing pain and potentially leading to blindness. Surgery is necessary to correct trichiasis and prevent further damage to the cornea.
  2. Antibiotics: Antibiotic treatment is provided to individuals with active trachoma (trachomatous inflammation-follicular, or TF) and their contacts to eliminate the infection and reduce transmission. Azithromycin or Tetracycline eye ointment are commonly used antibiotics for trachoma control programs.
  3. Facial cleanliness: Promoting face washing and hygiene practices, particularly among children and families in endemic areas, helps reduce the transmission of trachoma by preventing the spread of infectious ocular secretions.
  4. Environmental improvement: Environmental interventions such as improving access to water and sanitation facilities, along with promoting hygiene and sanitation practices, contribute to reducing the transmission of trachoma.

Evaluation of control program refers to assessing the effectiveness and impact of the trachoma control interventions implemented through the SAFE strategy. Evaluation is a crucial aspect of public health programs to monitor progress, identify challenges, and make informed decisions for program improvement, but is not considered a component of SAFE strategy (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: Most common cause of moderate to severe cause of visual impairment in India in adults:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cataract is the most common cause of moderate to severe visual impairment in adults in India.
  • Cataract is the clouding of the lens in the eye, leading to progressive loss of vision.
  • It is highly prevalent in India, particularly among older adults, and is a major cause of visual impairment and blindness.
  • Cataract surgery is one of the most commonly performed surgical procedures in India and is highly effective in restoring vision.

Incorrect options:

Diabetic retinopathy (Option A): Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes that affects the blood vessels of the retina. While it is a significant cause of visual impairment in individuals with diabetes, especially in developed countries with a high prevalence of diabetes, cataract remains the leading cause of visual impairment in the general adult population in India.

Refractory error (Option B): Refractive errors, such as myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), and astigmatism, are common causes of visual impairment worldwide. However, while refractive errors can cause visual impairment, they are typically correctable with prescription eyeglasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery.

Glaucoma (Option C): Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions characterized by damage to the optic nerve, often associated with elevated intraocular pressure. While glaucoma can lead to visual impairment and blindness, it is not as prevalent as cataract in India. However, glaucoma remains a significant public health concern, particularly due to its irreversible nature and the need for early detection and treatment to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: According to IMNCI, at what Respiratory Rate is it considered as 'Fast breathing' in a 5 month old:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In IMNCI, fast breathing is one of the danger signs used to assess respiratory distress in children. For infants aged 2 to 12 months, fast breathing is defined as a respiratory rate (RR) greater than or equal to 50 breaths per minute.

IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) is a strategy developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) to address the leading causes of childhood morbidity and mortality.

One of the key components of IMNCI is the identification and management of common childhood illnesses, including respiratory infections.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy of weight 12 kg presents to clinic with xerophtalmia and bitot's spots one the eyes. He is diagnosed as having vitamin A deficiency. what is oral dose of vitamin A to be administered in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For a child > 2 years of age, and > 8 kg body weight, 2 lakh I.U of Vitamin A is to be administered stat followed by 2 lakh I.U every 6 months till 5 years of age as prophylaxis.
  • Vitamin A deficiency is a significant public health concern, particularly in young children, as it can lead to a range of adverse health outcomes, including impaired growth, increased susceptibility to infections, and vision problems.
  • Supplementation with vitamin A is an essential intervention to address this deficiency, especially in populations where dietary intake of vitamin A-rich foods is insufficient.

questions.text: The dose of diphtheria antitoxin administered in a case of Diphtheria is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diphtheria antitoxin, also known as DAT, is a specific antiserum used to neutralize the diphtheria toxin produced by the bacteria Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

It is indicated for the treatment of suspected cases of diphtheria and for post-exposure prophylaxis in individuals who have been in close contact with a confirmed case of diphtheria.

Option A, C, D ruled out.

questions.text: The Chance of Vertical transmission of HIV from mother to child is highest with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High viral RNA load in the mother's blood is one of the strongest predictors of vertical transmission. When the maternal viral load is high, the risk of transmission to the child increases significantly, regardless of the mode of delivery or infant feeding method.

Maternal HIV viral load directly correlates with the risk of Vertical transmission, and effective ART to suppress viral replication is crucial in reducing this risk.

Incorrect options:

Elective caesarean section (Option A):

  • Elective caesarean section (C-section) delivery is recommended for HIV-positive pregnant women with high viral loads (viral load >1000 copies/mL near the time of delivery) to reduce the risk of vertical transmission.
  • C-section alone does not eliminate the risk of transmission if the viral load is high.

Breastfeeding (Option C): Breastfeeding by HIV-positive mothers poses a risk of vertical transmission, but the risk is lower compared to transmission during pregnancy or childbirth. With proper antiretroviral therapy (ART) and adherence to infant feeding guidelines, such as exclusive formula feeding or exclusive breastfeeding with maternal ART, the risk of transmission through breastfeeding can be significantly reduced.

Term delivery (Option D): Term delivery (delivery at or after 37 weeks of gestation) is not a risk factor for vertical transmission by itself.

choices.text: Single dose of Inj. Benzathine penicillin
3 weekly benzathine penicillin injections for 5 years or till 21 years whichever is later
3 weekly Benzathine penicillin injection for 5 years or till 25 years whichever is later

questions.text: A child, with history of Acute Rheumatic fever, presented with manifestation of Streptococcal infection but no carditis. What will you suggest for secondary prevention?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The recommended duration of secondary prophylaxis with benzathine penicillin is 3 weekly Benzathine Penicillin injections at least 5 years after the last episode of acute rheumatic fever or until the age of 21, whichever is longer (Option A, B, D ruled out).
  • This regimen helps prevent recurrent streptococcal infections and subsequent episodes of rheumatic fever during the period of greatest vulnerability.
  • Dose: 600,000 IU for children ≤27 kg; 1.2 million IU for children >27 kg.
  • If Carditis is present, prophylaxis will continue lifelong.

questions.text: A female presented to the clinic with anogenital warts. On gene study, it was found that she is at high risk of Cervical cancer. Which strain of HPV is most likely responsible for high risk of Cervial cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is a well-established risk factor for cervical cancer, particularly high-risk or oncogenic types of HPV.
  • HPV types are categorized based on their oncogenic potential, with certain types being associated with a higher risk of developing cervical cancer.
  • HPV 18 is one of the high-risk or Oncogenic types of HPV that is strongly associated with the development of cervical cancer.
  • Along with HPV 18, HPV 16 is responsible for a significant proportion of cervical cancer cases worldwide.
  • Persistent infection with HPV 18 can lead to precancerous changes in cervical cells, eventually progressing to cervical cancer.

Options A, B, C ruled out.

choices.text: 35 years to 55 years of age
21 years to 65 years of age

questions.text: Screening for Cervical carcinoma is done at:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cervical cancer screening aims to detect precancerous changes or early-stage cervical cancer in women, allowing for early intervention and treatment.

According to most guidelines, including those from organizations like the American Cancer Society and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, Screening typically begins at age 21 regardless of sexual activity (Option A, B, D ruled out) and is recommended:

  • Every 3 years with cytology (Pap smear) alone
  • Or every 5 years with high-risk HPV testing alone.

Screening may continue up to age 65, depending on previous screening history and risk factors.

questions.text: All of the following health disorders are covered under Child Health Screening and Early Intervention Program (RBSK) except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital glaucoma is a rare but serious eye condition characterized by increased pressure within the eye (intraocular pressure) due to abnormal development of the eye's drainage system. While early detection and treatment are crucial for managing congenital glaucoma, it is not typically included in the screening components of RBSK.

The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) or Child Health Screening and Early Intervention Program aims to screen children for various health disorders and provide early interventions to prevent or manage these conditions.

Incorrect options:

Childhood cataract (Option A): Childhood cataract refers to clouding of the lens of the eye in children, which can cause vision impairment or blindness if not treated promptly. RBSK includes screening for childhood cataract to detect cases early and refer them for appropriate treatment, which may involve surgery to remove the cataract and restore vision.

Retinopathy of prematurity (Option B): Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a potentially blinding eye disorder that primarily affects premature infants who have received intensive neonatal care, particularly those born before 32 weeks of gestation. RBSK includes screening for ROP in premature infants to detect signs of the condition early and provide timely treatment or monitoring to prevent vision loss.

Vitamin A deficiency (Option D): Vitamin A deficiency is a nutritional disorder that can lead to various health problems, including vision impairment and blindness, particularly in children. RBSK includes screening for vitamin A deficiency to identify at-risk children and provide supplementation or dietary interventions to prevent deficiency-related complications.

choices.text: Ferrous fumarate -Folic acid - Vitamin B12 - Vitamin C

questions.text: You are Medical officer at PHC. What will be your advice regarding an economical method for Mass drug administration for Iron deficiency anaemia in the catchment population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ferrous sulphate is one of the most commonly used and cost-effective oral iron supplements available.
  • It is readily available in various formulations, including tablets, syrups, and drops, making it suitable for mass distribution programs.
  • Ferrous sulphate is well-absorbed by the body and is effective in replenishing iron stores in individuals with iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia is a common nutritional deficiency worldwide, and mass drug administration (MDA) is one approach to address it in populations with a high prevalence.
  • When considering an economical method for MDA for iron deficiency anaemia, the primary goal is to choose an iron supplement that is cost-effective, safe, and readily available.

Incorrect options:

Intravenous iron (Option B): Intravenous iron therapy is not suitable for mass drug administration due to several factors. Firstly, it requires skilled healthcare personnel for administration, which may not be feasible in large-scale MDA programs. Secondly, intravenous iron is significantly more expensive than oral iron supplements, making it economically impractical for widespread distribution in populations with iron deficiency anaemia.

Ferrous fumarate - Folic acid - Vitamin B12 - Vitamin C (Option C): This combination contains additional nutrients such as folic acid, vitamin B12, and vitamin C, which are important for overall health and can support iron absorption. However, including these additional nutrients may increase the cost of the supplement, making it less economically feasible for MDA compared to ferrous sulphate alone.

Iron(III)-hydroxide polymaltose complex (Option D): Iron(III)-hydroxide polymaltose complex is another oral iron supplement that is well-absorbed and has good tolerability. However, it tends to be more expensive than ferrous sulphate and may not be as widely available, particularly in resource-constrained settings where cost-effectiveness is a primary consideration for MDA programs.

choices.text: It is a screening test for Cervical cancer
It is a diagnostic test for Cervical cancer
It is a screening for cancer of Female genital tract
It is a Diagnostic test for Trichomoniasis infection

questions.text: A woman with Recurrent Trichomoniasis infection was advised Pap smear. She asks you the purpose of the test. What would be your answer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pap smear, also known as Pap test or cervical cytology, is a screening test used to detect abnormal cervical cells, including precancerous cells and cervical cancer (Option B, C, D ruled out).
  • During a Pap smear, cells are collected from the cervix and examined under a microscope to detect any abnormal changes in the cervical cells that may indicate the presence of precancerous or cancerous lesions.
  • Early detection through Pap smear screening allows for timely intervention and treatment, reducing the risk of cervical cancer development.
  • According to most guidelines, including those from organizations like the American Cancer Society and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, Screening typically begins at age 21 regardless of sexual activity and is recommended:
    • Every 3 years with cytology (Pap smear) alone
    • Or every 5 years with high-risk HPV testing alone.
    • Screening may continue up to age 65, depending on previous screening history and risk factors.

questions.text: The HPV vaccine is based on
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The HPV vaccine is based on the L1 and L2 proteins of the virus.
  • These proteins are major and minor capsid proteins, respectively, which form the outer shell of the HPV virus.
  • The L1 protein, in particular, is highly immunogenic and serves as the primary target for HPV vaccines. By inducing an immune response against L1 and L2, the HPV vaccine helps prevent infection with HPV and reduces the risk of HPV-related cancers and genital warts.

Incorrect options:

E1, E2 (Option A): The E1 and E2 proteins are involved in the replication of the HPV virus.

E6, E7 (Option B, C): The E6 and E7 proteins are oncogenic proteins produced by high-risk HPV strains. They play a role in the development of HPV-related cancers by promoting cell proliferation and inhibiting apoptosis. While E6 and E7 are important targets for therapeutic interventions, they are not components of the HPV vaccine.

questions.text:
A Health worker is supposed to sanitize their hands under which of the following conditions:
(a) Before examining the patient
(b) After examining the patient
(c) After touching patients surroundings
(d) When you see your hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
Explanation:

(a) Before examining the patient: Sanitizing your hands before examining the patient is essential to prevent the transfer of potentially harmful microorganisms from your hands to the patient. This helps reduce the risk of healthcare-associated infections.

(b) After examining the patient: Sanitizing your hands after examining the patient is important to remove any potentially harmful microorganisms that may have been transferred from the patient to your hands during the examination. This helps prevent the spread of infections to other patients or healthcare workers.

(c) After touching patients' surroundings: Sanitizing your hands after touching patients' surroundings, such as bed rails, tables, or medical equipment, is necessary to minimize the risk of cross-contamination. Surfaces in healthcare settings can harbor various pathogens, and touching them can transfer these pathogens to your hands. Proper hand hygiene helps prevent the spread of infections between patients and healthcare workers.

(d) When you see your hands are visibly soiled: While hand sanitization is effective for reducing the number of microorganisms on the hands, it may not be sufficient to remove visible dirt, blood, or other bodily fluids. In such cases, washing hands with soap and water is recommended instead of hand sanitizer. Therefore, while hand sanitization is important, it is not the appropriate method for visibly soiled hands (Option B, C, D ruled out).

questions.text: Transplacental transmission of disease leading to Microcephaly is not seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to fetal hydrops and other complications, but it is not typically associated with microcephaly.
  • Parvoviruses are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses known for their ability to infect a wide range of hosts, including humans, animals, and even insects.
  • Transmission: Respiratory droplets, blood transfusions, vertical (mother to fetus).
  • Treatment: Supportive care (no specific antiviral); IVIG for chronic B19 in immunocompromised

Incorrect options:

Rubella virus (Option A): Rubella virus infection during pregnancy can also lead to congenital rubella syndrome, which may include birth defects such as microcephaly.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) (Option C): CMV infection during pregnancy is a known cause of congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which can lead to various birth defects, including microcephaly.

Zika virus (Option B): Zika virus infection during pregnancy can lead to transplacental transmission, resulting in a range of congenital abnormalities, including microcephaly.

questions.text: Life cycle Image of an organism is given below. Identify the organism involved:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above diagram shows the life cycle of Leptospira

  • Leptospirosis (Weil's disease) is a bacterial infection caused by Spirochetes of the genus Leptospira.
  • Transmission:
    • Direct/indirect contact with infected animal urine (rats, dogs, cattle, pigs).
    • High-risk exposures:
      • Floodwater exposure (tropical areas).
      • Occupational (farmers, sewer workers, veterinarians).
      • Recreational (swimming in contaminated lakes, adventure sports).
    • The life cycle of Leptospira involves both Environmental and Host components, which is depicted in the given image.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Mild (80-90% of cases): Flu-like illness (fever, headache, myalgia, conjunctival suffusion).
    • Severe (Weil's disease, 5-10%):
      • Jaundice, acute kidney injury, hemorrhagic pneumonitis.
      • Multi-organ failure (liver, kidneys, lungs).
      • Mortality: 5-20% in severe cases.
  • Prophylaxis & Prevention
    • General Measures
      • Avoid contaminated water (floodwater, stagnant ponds).
      • Protective gear (gloves, boots) for high-risk occupations.
      • Rodent control (reduce reservoir hosts).
    • Vaccination
      • No widely available human vaccine (some country-specific vaccines exist, e.g., Cuba, France).
      • Veterinary vaccines (dogs, livestock) help reduce transmission.
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis (Post-Exposure)
    • Doxycycline 200 mg once weekly (for short-term high-risk exposure, e.g., disaster relief workers).
    • Not routinely recommended for general populations.

Incorrect options:

Hanta virus (Option A): Hantaviruses are RNA viruses that are transmitted to humans primarily through aerosolized rodent urine, feces, or saliva. Hantaviruses primarily infect rodents and are not directly transmitted from human to human.

Yersinia pestis (Option C): Yersinia pestis is the bacterium that causes plague. Plague is primarily transmitted through the bites of infected fleas, which acquire the bacteria from infected rodents. The life cycle of Yersinia pestis involves the flea as a vector and various rodent species as reservoir hosts.

Rickettsia (Option D): Rickettsia is a genus of bacteria that includes species responsible for various diseases, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever and typhus. Rickettsia species are primarily transmitted to humans through arthropod vectors, such as ticks, fleas, and lice.

questions.text: In India pre transfusion screening is done for all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Unlike HIV, HBV, and malaria, dengue is not primarily transmitted through blood transfusions (Option A, B, C ruled out).
  • Dengue is a viral infection transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes mosquitoes.
  • While dengue can cause thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), which might necessitate blood transfusions in severe cases, routine screening for dengue in donated blood is not typically performed because the virus is not primarily transmitted through blood transfusions.
  • Instead, blood centers focus on screening for viruses that are more directly blood-borne, such as HIV, HBV, HCV, and malaria.

choices.text: Start the fresh cycle of DPT as 1st dose
Give the second dose of Pentavalent stat

questions.text: A 1-year-old child's mother comes to your immunisation clinic stating that the child received only the 1st dose of Pentavalent at 6 weeks. What's your plan?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Pentavalent vaccine is a combination vaccine that protects against five diseases:

  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis (whooping cough)
  • Tetanus
  • Hepatitis B
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib).

It is typically administered as part of the routine immunization schedule for infants.

In this scenario, the child received the first dose of Pentavalent vaccine at 6 weeks of age. According to the recommended immunization schedule, the second dose of Pentavalent vaccine is usually administered at 10 weeks of age. Since the child missed the scheduled second dose, the appropriate action would be to administer the missed dose as soon as possible.

National immunization Schedule:

questions.text: HPV vaccine in the age group below 14 years is given as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The HPV (Human Papillomavirus) vaccine is recommended for the prevention of HPV infections, which can lead to various cancers, including cervical cancer, in both males and females.
  • The dosing schedule for the HPV vaccine varies depending on the age at which the vaccine is initiated.
  • For individuals aged below 15 years, the HPV vaccine is typically administered in 2 doses, with the second dose given 6 to 12 months after the first dose. This dosing schedule has been found to be effective in providing strong protection against HPV infection and associated diseases.

Reference: HPV Vaccine Schedule and Dosing | CDC
